Multiphase catalysts with heterointerfaces have shown compelling potential in catalyzing oxidative mineralization of pollutants. In particular, the interfacial electron communication of heterointerfaces is beneficial for activation of reactant molecules through promotive interfacial electron transfer efficiency. In this study, a MnO2/CoMn2O4 heterojunction catalyst was constructed for the electron-rich Co centers and abundant redox pairs. Benefiting from the synergistic interaction between cobalt (Co2+/Co3+) and manganese (Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+) at the active sites, as well as the electron density difference between the interfaces of the two phases, a significant enhancement of the catalytic activity for peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation was achieved. Systematic characterization analysis revealed that the catalyst has highly active catalytic sites characterized by electron-rich Co2+, and the electron-donating property of the high-electron-density Co2+ active sites in the A site of spinel CoMn2O4 promotes the efficient transfer of electrons and the rapid generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) from PMS activation. More exposed catalytic active sites and significantly lower interfacial mass transfer resistance further enhanced the activation performance of the catalysts for bisphenol A degradation by these ROS. The optimal MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 exhibited a optimal BPA degradation activity (86 %, kobs = 0.316 min-1) and excellent resistance to anionic interference. The results of free radical quenching experiments indicated that single linear oxygen (1O2) and hydroxyl radical (·OH) were the main active substances for PMS activation and BPA degradation. This study provides meaningful insights into the improvement of heterojunction interfacial systems for catalytic efficiency enhancement and environmental remediation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heterojunction catalyst Heterointerfaces PMS activation, Bisphenol A Interfacial electron transfer Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the increasingly severe global environmental problems, the threat of pollutants to ecosystems and human health is becoming more serious [1], especially the discharge of organic pollutants [2] has become an urgent environmental issue to be solved. Bisphenol A (BPA), as a typical endocrine disruptor [3], has attracted high attention from the scientific community [4] due to its wide presence in environmental media such as water and soil. BPA can interfere with the normal function of the endocrine system in organisms [5], thereby affecting many physiological processes including reproduction, development, and the immune system, which emphasizes the urgency of efficient degradation of BPA. In recent years, peroxymonosulfate (PMS) has been widely used in the field of pollutant degradation due to its ability to generate multiple active species [6,7], including sulfate radicals (SO4·⁻), hydroxyl radicals (·OH), and singlet oxygen (1O2) [8]. However, the sole use of PMS for efficient degradation has limitations [9], and the addition of a catalyst has been proven to be an important way to improve the activation efficiency of PMS [10]. Therefore, the development of efficient and stable PMS activation catalysts has become a key to further enhancing degradation performance [11]. Among all kinds of water treatment methods, adsorption [12], photocatalysis [13–15] and microwave catalysis [16,17] are considered as the current research hotspots. Compared with the above technologies, transition metal oxide based AOPs has attracted much attention due to its controllable redox characteristics and high stability. However, single-component catalysts often limit their application due to insufficient active sites and low electron transport efficiency. Among various catalyst systems, manganese-based (Mn-based) and cobalt-based (Co-based) materials have attracted much attention due to their excellent electron transfer ability and rich redox properties [18,19]. Manganese oxide (MnO2) has been widely used in the degradation of organic pollutants due to its rich crystal structure and adjustable oxidation state changes [20,21]. Cobalt-based spinel (CoMn2O4) has a stable structure and a bimetallic synergy effect [22], showing excellent performance in the activation of PMS [23,24]. Nevertheless, certain drawbacks come to the fore when these two materials are employed independently as catalysts. In the case of MnO2, it is prone to issues like the diminution of active sites and a deterioration in stability during extended reaction periods [25,26]. Although CoMn2O4 has a stable structure, it encounters a bottleneck in further enhancing its catalytic activity and struggles to fully meet the stringent requirements for the efficient degradation of BPA in complex environments [27]. Hence, a strategy that can synergistically combine the merits of MnO2 and CoMn2O4 while overcoming their individual limitations is highly desirable [28]. Recently, heterointerface catalysts have received extensive attention due to their unique interface effects and significant catalytic performance [29,30]. It has been shown that heterointerfaces not only can enhance the transfer efficiency of electrons within the catalyst [31,32] but also have the potential to significantly alter the electronic environment of active centers through the regulation of interface structures [33,34], promoting the generation and participation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in reactions [35,36]. Based on this, a heterointerface catalyst MnO2/CoMn2O4 for activating PMS to degrade BPA was prepared with Zeolitic Imidazolate Framework-67 (ZIF-67) as a sacrificial template. By carefully controlling the initial addition of reactants and calcination temperature, the effects of the Co/Mn ratio and the strength of interface interaction on degradation activity were investigated. MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 exhibited optimal BPA degradation activity (86 %, kobs = 0.316 min-1) and excellent resistance to anion interference. Detailed characterization results indicated that the superior catalytic activity of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 was attributed to the formation of a heterointerface and the electron enrichment effect of the active center Co2+. The electron-rich Co2+ achieved rapid electron transfer through the MnO2/CoMn2O4 hetero-interface, which significantly contributed to the activation efficiency of the PMS and the generation of ROS. Free radical burst experiments confirmed that 1O2 and ⋅OH were the main active substances. Efficient BPA removal was realized under the synergistic effect of Co2+/Co3+ and Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+ redox cycles. This study revealed the synergistic mechanism of heterointerfaces and electron-rich active centers in enhancing catalyst performance, providing a theoretical basis for the development of efficient and stable environmental catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemical and reagent Tert-butanol (99.5 %, TBA), l-histidine (99 %, l-his), P-benzoquinone (98 %, p-BQ), dopamine hydrochloride (98 %, C8H12ClNO2), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (98 %, Co(NO3)2·6H2O), 2-methylimidazole (99.9 %, C4H6N2), Potassium peroxymonosulfate complex salt (PMS), methanol (99.9 %, MeOH) and ethanol absolute were obtained by Energy Chemicals Co, Ltd. Potassium permanganate (99.5 %, KMnO4) and hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (99 %, C19H42BrN) were acquired from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd. Ammonium hydroxide (AR, NH3·H2O) was purchased from Chinasun Specialty Products Co, Ltd. Sodium chloride (99.7 %, NaCl), sodium carbonate (AR, Na2CO3), sodium bicarbonate (99.5 %, NaHCO3), sodium sulphate (99.5 %, Na2SO4), Sodium bisulfate(99.5 %, NaHSO4), sodium hydroxide (AR, NaOH) were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Industrial Co, LTD. All the chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Material synthesis The ZIF-67 was fabricated by a reported synthetic method. First, 3.314 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 11.208 g of 2-methylimidazole were dissolved in 250 mL of methanol, respectively. Then, the 2-methylimidazole solution was slowly added to the Co(NO3)2·6H2O solution under vigorous mechanical stirring to form a purple mixed solution. The two solutions were completely mixed after another 30 min stirring, followed by standing at room temperature for 24 h. Finally, the purple precipitate (ZIF-67) was collected by centrifugation at 9000 rpm for 5 min and washed repeatedly with methanol, and then dried at 70 °C overnight. After that, 0.06 g of ZIF-67 was added into the mixed solution of 30 mL of EtOH and 40 mL of H2O, and the ZIF-67 was completely dispersed by ultrasound for 10 min. Then, 0.2 g of potassium permanganate, 30 mg of dopamine hydrochloride, 0.2 g of CTAB and 0.2 mL of 1 mol l-1 hydrochloric acid were added into the above solution, and mechanical stirring was performed for 30 min. The mixed solution was then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-coated autoclave for a hydrothermal reaction at 100 °C for 6 h, then centrifuged at 9000 rpm for 5 min to harvest the grey-black solid, washed and precipitated with a large amount of EtOH, and dried overnight in an oven at 70 °C. The obtained samples were calcined in argon atmosphere at different temperatures (400, 500 and 600 °C, 3 h, 5 °C/min). They are listed as CoMn2O4–4, MnO2/CoMn2CoO4–5, and MnO2/CoMn2O4–6, respectively. At the same time, according to the content of cobalt elements of different ratios of 0.1:1, 0.2:1, 0.3:1, 0.4:1, 0.5:1, 1:1 respectively made samples to Co/Mn(0.02)-5, Co/Mn(0.04)-5, Co/Mn(0.06)-5, Co/Mn(0.08)-5, Co/Mn(0.1)-5, Co/Mn(0.2)-5. Co-5 is synthesized by calcining ZIF-67 at 500 °C for 3 h in an argon atmosphere. 2.3 Characterization Field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S4800 by Hitachi) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100 F by JEOL) were used to determine the morphology of the samples. The crystal state of the material and the possible phase states of active Co and Cu were determined by wide-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD, XRD-6000 X by Shimadzu). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, 5000 VP by ULVACPHI) was used to determine the elemental composition, content, and chemical state of the whole material. Raman spectra were obtained at room temperature with a Spex 1877 D triple companion spectrometer. Linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were carried out on a CHI760E electrochemical workstation using a standard three-electrode method, where a platinum electrode and Ag/AgCl were used as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. 2.4 Catalytic performance assessment To systematically evaluate the catalytic efficacy of the catalysts, Bisphenol A catalytic elimination with PMS as an oxidant was carried out. An ultraviolet spectrophotometer (MAPADA P1800) was used to measure the dynamic concentration change of Bisphenol A (which started at 20 mg l-1) during the reaction. Specifically, A certain amount of PMS was dispersed in 50 mL of 20 mg L −1 Bisphenol A solution, and then the catalyst was added to the above solution. In the reaction progress, at regular intervals, a tiny sample of the reaction solution was removed from the reactor for testing and analysis using an ultraviolet spectrophotometer. By altering the concentrations of the catalyst, PMS, and Bisphenol A, but leaving the remaining reaction conditions unaltered, control experiments were conducted to optimize the reaction parameters. The MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 catalyst from the previous cycle was regenerated by centrifugation, washed alternately with ethanol and water, dried in a vacuum at 60 °C, and then calcined at 300 °C for 2 h. In the following cycle experiments, the reprocessed catalyst was redispersed into a new Bisphenol A solution containing PMS for degradation experiments. The quenching experiments using various quenching agents without change of other reaction conditions were performed to explore the reaction course change of optimal catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 a describes the formation process from the preparation of the initial precursor to the final composite material, providing in-depth insights into the synthesis of the MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 catalyst. Fig. 1 b shows a representative SEM image of Co-5 obtained after calcination of ZIF-67, from which it is observed that the nanoparticles have a certain degree of agglomeration. A clear inner and outer layer separation boundary was observed in the low-resolution TEM image of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 (Fig. 1 c). The catalyst surface is rough, and the internal particle size is about 80 nm. The rough surface characteristics are often conducive to the rapid adsorption of reactants on its surface. Furthermore, the lattice fringes of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 are clearly captured in the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image in Fig. 1 d, which indicates that the prepared catalyst has high crystallinity. High crystallinity is of great significance to the improvement of catalyst stability and catalytic activity. The lattice spacings of 0.247 nm and 0.274 nm observed in the inverse fast Fourier transform (inverse FFT) pattern of the selected area correspond to the (213) crystal plane of CoMn2O4 and the (411) crystal plane of MnO2, respectively (Fig. 1 e), which provides strong evidence for determining the structural composition of the catalyst. In addition, the distinct contrast in the high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image further confirms that the catalyst is composed of two different phases (Fig. 1 f). The element mapping intuitively shows the distribution of Co, Mn, and O elements in MnO2/CoMn2O4–5. It is worth noting that the Co element shows a relatively concentrated distribution in the inner layer of the polyhedron. Although the Mn element is observed in the entire selected area, the darker color represents its high content distribution in the polyhedron. In contrast, the O element is almost uniformly distributed within the selection [37,38]. The above analytical results imply that the heterogeneous interfacial catalyst with CoMn2O4 as the core MnO2 as the surface coating was successfully constructed. The crystal structures of CoMn2O4–4, MnO2/CoMn2O4–5, and MnO2/CoMn2O4–6, Co-5 catalysts were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD) to determine the effect of calcination temperature and preparation strategy on the catalyst compositional state. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the XRD diffraction peaks of the CoMn2O4–4 catalyst prepared at lower temperatures correspond to the standard card of CoMn2O4 (PDF#04–001–7706). As the calcination temperature was increased, additional diffraction peaks corresponding to MnO2 (PDF#00–044–0141) appeared in the spectra of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 and MnO2/CoMn2O4–6. This phenomenon may be attributed to the phase transition of the catalyst due to the higher calcination temperature, where some manganese ions detached from the original CoMn2O4 lattice structure and rearranged to form the MnO2 lattice structure. Therefore, it was inferred that the calcination temperature played an important role in the construction of heterogeneous interfacial MnO2/CoMn2O4 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2 b, the Co-5 catalyst obtained by direct calcination of ZIF-67 consists of monolithic Co anchored by carbon skeleton. In order to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the coordination environments of the elemental states on the catalyst surface after the addition of a manganese source, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [39–41] characterization of Co-5 and MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 was carried out. The XPS results confirmed that the catalysts consisted of predominantly C, O, and the corresponding associated metal elements (Fig. 2 c). In addition, the detailed elemental composition of the catalyst extracted from the XPS results is further summarized in Table. S1–3. The typical core energy levels in the fine XPS spectra of Co 2p were determined to be as Co2+ and Co3+ and satellite peaks (Fig. 2 d). The Co2+ of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 was deconvolved at 780.4 eV and 796.2 eV, and the Co3+ deconvolved at 783.5 eV and 798.4 eV. Redox cycling between Co2+ and Co3+ plays a key role in the activation of potassium peroxymonosulfate (PMS) for the degradation of bisphenol A (BPA). Co2+ ions promote the decomposition of PMS by providing electrons during PMS activation to generate strongly oxidizing reactive oxygen species (ROS). Compared with Co-5, the anticonvolution peak of Co2+ of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 shifted to a lower binding energy, indicating that Co2+ was in an electron-rich binding environment, and the higher electron cloud density was favorable for the generation of more ROS. In addition, Co3+ acted as an electron acceptor and ensured the degradation reaction by efficiently adsorbing PMS molecules. Therefore, changes in the Co2+/Co3+ ratio affect the efficiency of the redox cycle and the electron transfer process on the catalyst surface. Obviously, the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ in MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 is closer to 1, implying that the redox cycle can be sustained and efficiently carried out in this system. The typical core energy levels in the fine XPS spectra of Mn 2p were identified as Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+ (Fig. 2 e). Similar to Co 2p, the multivalent Mn ions can form an effective redox cycle among themselves, ensuring the continuity of the electron transfer process. The excellent synergistic effect of Co/Mn active sites contributes to the significant improvement of the catalytic activity [42]. In Fig. 2 f, the spectrum of O 1 s contains three fitted peaks of lattice oxygen OL (66.21 %), vacancy oxygen OV (22.44 %), and adsorbed oxygen OA (11.35 %). Especially, OV provides further assurance for the production of more ROS species as additional active sites during PMS activation [43,44]. To further investigate the electron transfer and transport properties of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 catalyst, we conducted comprehensive electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), and open circuit voltage (OCV) measurements. In the EIS test (Fig. 3 a), the catalysts obtained at different calcination temperatures exhibited similar arc shapes. However, MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 showed a steeper slope, implying that it possesses a very low charge transfer resistance and an efficient interfacial charge transfer rate. This intrinsic electrochemical advantage may be attributed to the generation of electron-rich Co2+ active sites and the successful construction of the MnO2/CoMn2O4 heterointerface. The formation of electron-rich Co2+ active sites contributes significantly to the excellent electrochemical performance. During the activation of PMS by MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 for the degradation of BPA, the electron-rich Co2+ active sites exhibit a strong electron-donating tendency by virtue of their high electron cloud density. In the interaction with PMS, these Co2+ active sites can rapidly transfer electrons to PMS, thereby strongly driving the decomposition of PMS and generating reactive oxygen species with strong oxidizing properties. The special structure of the MnO2/CoMn2O4 heterogeneous interface further guarantees the smoothness and continuity of the electron transfer. Fig. 3 b shows that MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 exhibits the highest corrosion potential (0.878 eV) among all catalysts. It is worth noting that the corrosion potentials of the series of catalysts are all positive, indicating that the catalysts are resistant to corrosion and deactivation. Compared with other comparative catalysts, MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 exhibits the strongest corrosion resistance, which generally means that it has higher stability. The higher stability is due to the interfacial interaction between MnO2 and CoMn2O4, which contributes to the lifetime of the catalyst during the cycle. The interaction strength of the MnO2/CoMn2O4 series catalysts with PMS was evaluated by open circuit voltage (OCV) analysis (Fig. 3 c). Upon the addition of PMS, the MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 catalysts exhibited a greater voltage change, indicating a stronger interaction between the catalysts and PMS. The electron-rich nature of the Co2+ active site can contribute to the easier approach of PMS molecules to the catalyst surface through electrostatic attraction, significantly increasing the probability and rate of BPA degradation reaction [45]. Within the domain of chemical catalysis, the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) is a pivotal parameter for evaluating catalyst performance, as it is intrinsically linked to the active site density of the catalyst surface. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) serves as a standard technique for ascertaining the ECSA of catalysts. The specific results of cyclic voltammetry are shown in Fig. S1. As illustrated in Fig. 3 d, the ECSA measurements for CoMn2O4–4, MnO2/CoMn2O4–5, and MnO2/CoMn2O4–6 are 1.44 mF cm-2, 2.24 mF cm-2, and 1.8 mF cm-2, respectively. It is evident that MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 possesses the highest ECSA, signifying a greater number of active sites available for catalytic engagement. The increased active site availability on MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 is instrumental in enhancing the kinetics of the catalytic reactions, thereby bolstering the overall efficiency of the degradation process. 3.2 Catalytic performance and mechanism To further explore the influence of the synergistic effect of metal active species on the target reaction, a series of heterogeneous interface catalysts with different Co/Mn mass ratios were prepared by changing the initial addition amount of ZIF-67. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the degradation activity test was carried out in a BPA solution with a concentration of 30 mg l-1. The catalysts obtained by adjusting the Co/Mn mass ratio showed significantly different effects on the degradation of BPA. The corresponding pseudo-first-order reaction kinetic constants more intuitively illustrate this result (Fig. 4 b). There is a strong correlation between the Co/Mn mass ratio and the catalytic performance, highlighting the importance of optimizing the composition to obtain excellent activity. When the Co/Mn mass ratio is 0.06 and 0.2, the catalyst achieves excellent results with similar activity, which means that the number and accessibility of the active sites of the catalyst have reached an ideal balance. Considering the economic practicality and specific activity of the catalyst, the Co/Mn mass ratio of 0.06 was determined as the optimal ratio for the active sites to play an extreme role. Under the same experimental conditions, the construction of the heterogeneous interface was further explored to promote the activation of PMS to degrade BPA. As shown in Fig. 4 c, the catalysts CoMn2O4–4 and MnO2/CoMn2O4–6 showed similar degradation rates within the measurement time, while the degradation rate of BPA by MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 reached 85 % within 10 min, and the corresponding pseudo-first-order reaction kinetic constant was as high as kobs = 0.431 (Fig. 4 d). In addition, qualitative analysis by 3D fluorescence analysis in Fig. S2 confirmed the decrease of BPA content during the degradation reaction, confirming the results of UV absorption spectroscopic analysis. The excellent degradation activity of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 verifies the outstanding potential of the synergistic effect between Co and Mn active sites and the formation of a special interface in promoting redox cycles and electron transfer. The low charge transfer resistance ensures that electrons migrate efficiently on the catalyst surface, which is very beneficial for promoting the activation of PMS to degrade BPA [46]. In addition, more exposed electron-rich Co2+ active sites make it easier for PMS molecules to approach the catalyst surface through electrostatic attraction [47], thereby significantly increasing the rate of BPA degradation reaction. A series of controlled experiments were conducted to determine the effects of reaction parameters on the effectiveness of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 activated PMS for BPA degradation by modulating the catalyst dosage, PMS addition, and BPA concentration. Fig. 5 (a, d) shows that the degradation rate of BPA was significantly accelerated with increasing the catalyst MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 dosage from 0.2 g l-1 to 0.3 g l-1, corresponding to an increase in the kinetic constant from kobs = 0.114 to kobs = 0.431. However, the corresponding degradation rate and degradation activity decreased when the catalyst dosage was further increased to 0.4 g l-1. This result suggests that increasing the catalyst dosage can provide more active sites for the catalytic reaction, and the increased collision opportunities between the reactant BPA and the active sites can contribute to the rapid increase of the reaction rate. However, when the catalyst dosage is too high, it may lead to the agglomeration or shielding effect between the active sites, which makes some of them ineffective in participating in the reaction, thus limiting the further enhancement of the degradation rate. Fig. 5 (b, e) shows the degradation curves of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 at different PMS additions. When the PMS dosage was increased from 0.2 g l-1 to 0.3 g l-1, the degradation rate of BPA was significantly accelerated, which was attributed to the generation of a large number of reactive oxygen species in the system. Continuing to increase the dosage of PMS to 0.4 g l-1, the mineralization efficiency of BPA decreased in the assay time, which may be attributed to the autolytic reaction that occurs in excess of PMS, resulting in a decrease in the utilization of reactive oxygen species. The initial concentration of BPA also affected the degradation effect of the reaction system. As depicted in Fig. 5 (c, f), the degradation rate exhibited a volcano-like trend when the initial concentration of BPA was increased from 20 ppm to 40 ppm, which is consistent with the expected decrease in the reaction rate due to the mass transfer limitation at higher pollutant concentrations. The BPA mineralization performance of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 was affected by the availability of the active sites and the generation of ROS [48]. Moreover, it is also closely related to the ability of Co/Mn active sites to activate PMS and electron participation in redox reactions [49]. Therefore, exploring the reaction parameters may not only optimize the degradation process but also provide insight into the intrinsic reasons controlling the catalyst activity. In order to further verify the feasibility of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5, the catalytic degradation performance of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 on oxytetracycline (OTC), tetracycline (TC), carbamazepine (CBZ), bisphenol A (BPA) and other stubborn pollutants was further investigated. Fig. S3 shows the catalytic performance and corresponding kinetic curves of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 degradation of different pollutants. Under the same conditions, other pollutants were also degraded and a reasonable removal rate was achieved. The effect of HSO4 -, SO4 2-, Cl-, HCO3 - and OH- anions on the activity of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 in the catalytic degradation of bisphenol A (BPA) was systematically evaluated under controlled experimental conditions. Fig. 6 (a, b) shows that the activity curves of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 degradation of BPA in the presence of different anions exhibit significant differences. Among them, SO4 2-, Cl-, and HCO3 - had less inhibitory effects on BPA degradation, while HSO4 - and OH- had stronger inhibitory effects on BPA degradation. It is well known that SO4 2- and Cl- are relatively inert anions, and they interact weakly with the catalyst through electrostatic adsorption. This process produces negligible interference with the binding of BPA molecules to the active site and the reaction process. The addition of HCO3 - creates a buffer system that modulates the pH of the solution, and this modulation is unlikely to have a significant negative effect on the activity of the catalyst. The stronger inhibitory effect of the HSO4 - and OH- anions can be achieved by their higher basicity and ability to form stronger complexes with the catalyst. The stronger inhibitory effect of HSO4 - and OH- anions can be rationalized by their higher basicity and ability to form stronger complexes with the catalyst. The presence of HSO4 - and OH- may lead to the formation of less reactive species, thus reducing the ability of the catalyst to promote ROS generation and BPA degradation. In addition, OH- may form hydroxyl complexes with metal ions (Mn and Co) on the catalyst surface, which further reduces the accessibility and activity of the active site, resulting in a stronger inhibition of BPA degradation. The above results emphasize the importance of anion selectivity in catalytic systems. The cyclic degradation activity of the catalysts is another important criterion for evaluating the sustainability of the materials. The MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 catalyst was recovered by centrifugation to evaluate its reusability [50]. As shown in Fig. 6 c, the degradation efficiency of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 slightly decreased after five cycles, which implies that it has some potential for practical applications. Numerous studies have shown that the reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated during peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation are mainly composed of sulfate radicals (·SO4 −), hydroxyl radicals (·OH), superoxide radicals (·O2 −), and singlet oxygen (1O2). To elucidate the activation-oxidation mechanism of the MnO2/CoMn2O4–5/PMS system and determine the relative contribution of ROS in the degradation of BPA, a series of free radical scavenging experiments were performed. l-histidine (L-his), p-benzoquinone (p-BQ), and tert‑butyl alcohol (TBA) were selected as quenchers of 1O2, ·O2 -, and ·OH, respectively. Methanol (MeOH) was used as a quencher for the determination of ·OH and ·SO4 − radicals. TBA showed a keen reactivity to ·OH and a low reactivity to ·SO4 −. Therefore, the relative contribution of ·OH and ·SO4 − can be determined by MeOH and TBA. As shown in Fig. 6 d, the catalytic activity of MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 changed to varying degrees after the addition of l-His, TBA, MeOH and p-BQ quenchers, and the corresponding kobs decreased from 0.431 min-1 to 0.206 min-1, 0.201 min-1, 0.187 min-1 and 0.358 min-1, respectively (Fig. 6 e). By calculating the contribution of different ROS, it was found that 1O2 (52.2 %) and ⋅OH (53.4 %) were the main active substances produced during the catalyst activation of PMS, and ⋅SO4 - (3.2 %) contributed the least activity in the BPA mineralization process. In association, there is a lattice mismatch and electron cloud density difference at the heterogeneous interface formed by MnO2 and CoMn2O4, which promotes the formation of electron-rich Co2+ active sites in the bulk phase of the catalyst [51]. The electron-donating effect of electron-rich Co2+ promotes the breaking of peroxide bonds (OO) in PMS to generate 1O2. At the same time, the smaller mass transfer resistance and efficient electron transfer process are conducive to the PMS molecules obtaining electrons on the catalyst surface, thereby promoting the decomposition of PMS to produce ⋅OH. The results shown in Fig. 6 f confirm that the generated 1O2 and ·OH jointly participate in the oxidative degradation of BPA. Based on the above analysis, a possible reaction mechanism [52] for the degradation of BPA during the activation of PMS by MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 is proposed. First of all, PMS molecules are preferentially adsorbed on the surface of the MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 heterojunction catalyst. Benefiting from the reduced interfacial mass transfer resistance at the MnO2/CoMn2O4 heterojunction, PMS is more accessible to the active sites on the catalyst surface (Eq. (1)). Secondly, the electron-rich Co2+ active center acts as the initial active site, inducing the breaking of the peroxygen bond (OO) [53] in the PMS by supplying electrons to the PMS, generating ⋅SO4 - and ⋅OH radicals while being oxidized to Co3+ (Eq. (2)). The generated Co3+ acquires electrons from other substances and returns to the Co2+ state, maintaining the Co2+/Co3+ redox equilibrium (Eq. (3)). Subsequently, the two SO5 - react with the H2O to produce oxygen in the single linear state (1O2) (Eq. (4)). At the same time, Mn2+ in the system starts to participate in the reaction. Mn2+ is oxidized to Mn3+ by PMS while producing ⋅SO4 - and hydroxide ions (OH-) (Eq. (5)). Mn3+ is further oxidized by PMS to Mn4+ and produces peroxysulfate radicals (⋅SO5 -) (Eq. (6)). As an electron-donating active center, Mn4+ obtains electrons from electron-rich Co2+ [54]and then reverts back to the Mn3+ or Mn2+ state to maintain the Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+ redox ring cycle (Eq. (7)). The generated 1O2 and ⋅OH act as the main reactive substances attacking the BPA molecule [55]. They progressively degrade BPA into small molecule products through a series of complex oxidative reactions, which are ultimately converted into carbon dioxide and water (Eq. (8)). The Co2+/Co3+ redox ring and the Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+ redox ring synergize with each other throughout the reaction process. Co2+/Co3+ redox ring [56] promotes the activation of PMS through the transfer of electrons to produce ⋅SO4 - and ⋅OH, while Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+ redox ring provides additional reactive oxygen species generation pathways and redox activity for the system. The described reaction process ensures the uninterrupted generation and conversion of 1O2 and ⋅OH, and finally realizes the efficient BPA catalytic degradation process. The degradation mechanism is as follows: (1) PMS + Catalyst surface ⇌ PMS@Catalyst surface (2) Co2+ + PMS → Co3+ + ⋅OH+⋅SO4 − (3) Co3+ + HSO5 - → Co2+ + SO5 − + H+ (4) 2SO5 − + H2O → 1O2 + 2 HSO5 − (5) Mn2+ + HSO5 − → Mn3+ + ⋅SO4 − + OH⁻ (6) 2 Mn3+ + 2HSO5 − → Mn4+ + ⋅SO5 − + H+ (7) Mn4+ + Co2+ → Mn3+ + Co3+ (8) 1O2 +⋅OH + BPA → intermediate products → CO2 + H2O 4 Conclusions In this study, a highly effective MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 heterojunction catalyst was designed and fabricated, which demonstrated excellent performance in the active degradation of BPA by PMS. The structural advantages, abundant active sites and low interfacial mass transfer resistance of the catalyst are the key factors for its high performance. Free radical quenching experiments show that ¹O₂ and ⋅OH are the main active substances, and the cyclic stability and anti-anion interference experiments highlight their potential application value in practical wastewater treatment. Specifically, the MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 catalyst shows promising applications in practical wastewater treatment. Its high efficiency of PMS activation and degradation of organic pollutants such as BPA enable it to effectively treat industrial wastewater and municipal sewage containing endocrine disruptors. In addition, the high stability and recyclability of the catalyst give it the potential for long-term application in continuously operating wastewater treatment systems. In the field of fuel cells, the excellent properties of the MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 catalyst also have important applications. Its efficient electron transfer ability and abundant active sites make it can be used as an efficient oxygen reduction catalyst to improve the energy conversion efficiency and stability of fuel cells. However, there are still some scalability challenges to achieving large-scale adoption of the MnO2/CoMn2O4–5. The preparation cost of catalyst, the technical problems of scaling up production and the stability in complex environment need to be further studied and optimized. Future research can focus on the development of large-scale preparation technology of catalysts, performance evaluation in different practical wastewater treatment scenarios, and synergistic application with other technologies to promote their widespread application in the field of environmental remediation and energy. coredata.dc:description: Multiphase catalysts with heterointerfaces have shown compelling potential in catalyzing oxidative mineralization of pollutants. In particular, the interfacial electron communication of heterointerfaces is beneficial for activation of reactant molecules through promotive interfacial electron transfer efficiency. In this study, a MnO2/CoMn2O4 heterojunction catalyst was constructed for the electron-rich Co centers and abundant redox pairs. Benefiting from the synergistic interaction between cobalt (Co2+/Co3+) and manganese (Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+) at the active sites, as well as the electron density difference between the interfaces of the two phases, a significant enhancement of the catalytic activity for peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation was achieved. Systematic characterization analysis revealed that the catalyst has highly active catalytic sites characterized by electron-rich Co2+, and the electron-donating property of the high-electron-density Co2+ active sites in the A site of spinel CoMn2O4 promotes the efficient transfer of electrons and the rapid generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) from PMS activation. More exposed catalytic active sites and significantly lower interfacial mass transfer resistance further enhanced the activation performance of the catalysts for bisphenol A degradation by these ROS. The optimal MnO2/CoMn2O4–5 exhibited a optimal BPA degradation activity (86 %, kobs = 0.316 min-1) and excellent resistance to anionic interference. The results of free radical quenching experiments indicated that single linear oxygen (1O2) and hydroxyl radical (·OH) were the main active substances for PMS activation and BPA degradation. This study provides meaningful insights into the improvement of heterojunction interfacial systems for catalytic efficiency enhancement and environmental remediation.

coredata.dc:title: Construction of electron-rich Co centers and abundant redox pairs in MnO2/CoMn2O4 heterointerfaces for PMS activation and water purification
